info.title: The Text Alignment Network: Recommended IRI Vocabularies
Text Alignment Network: Recommended IRI Vocabularies

legalnotice.remark: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

revdescription.para: Prepublication working draft, for private circulation only. Corrections are actively solicited and should be sent to the author (see above).

warning.para: This version is known to have significant errors and omissions. In case of contradictions (apparent or not) between the schemas and these guidelines, the greatest weight is to be given to the RELAX-NG schemas, then to these guidelines, and then to the Schematron schemas.

This appendix has been written piecemal, as different IRI vocabularies and specific IRIs have needed a place to reside until they could be better organized. TAN-minted IRIs are not to be viewed as published, and should not be used until otherwise indicated.

preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: The reliance of TAN upon IRIs to describe many kinds of things or concepts means that anyone who creates TAN files will need to have at hand reliable resources from which to draw upon vocabulary that already exists. This chapter provides a guide to those resources, beginning with stable, well-known vocabularies that already exist and then listing IRI vocabulary that the Text Alignment Network has minted.

This appendix has been prepared to collect specialized IRI vocabularies recommended for use in TAN files. Listed below are TAN elements that require IRIs for concepts that are already well defined by other vocabularies. Useful Vocabularies for TAN IRIs

chapter.title: Normalization
chapter.para: The IRIs listed below attach to normalizations that should be understood broadly and therefore subjectively defined. Such declarations are not meant to help restore an original source, but to alert users as to what wholesale alterations have been made to a source.

row.entry: Discretionary word-break line-end hyphens have been deleted.
Footnote or endnote signals (frequently superscript numbers or letters) have been deleted.
Footnotes or endnotes have been deleted.
Reference pointers to other texts, both internal (cross-references) and external (citations of primary or secondary sources) have been deleted.
Reference milestones such as page numbers and section numbers have been deleted.
All ligatures have been converted into constituent letters.
All combining letters (U+0363..U+036F) have been converted to their corresponding ASCII counterpart.
All orthography (spelling) has been tacitly corrected to standard forms.
All punctuation has been tacitly corrected to standard forms.
All letters have been tacitly capitalized according to standard forms.
All uppercase letters converted to lowercase.
All lowercase letters converted to uppercase.
All prepunctuation space has been corrected according to standard forms.
All non-NFC-compliant Unicode converted to normalized Unicode. Same effect as if applying normalize-unicode().

chapter.title: Transliterations
chapter.para: In general, transliteration IRIs are composed by joining via colons (1) the TAN namespace, (2) transliteration, (3) the language code that best fits the source alphabet, (4) the language code that best fits the target alphabet, (5) a name of the transliteration scheme. Because these elements are not predictable, especially the last one, this section will accumulate names for valid, relevant transliteration schemes.
In the table below TBD indicates a code that has not yet been placed (work in progress).

entry.link: Thesaurus Linguae Graecae Beta Code, version 2013
